P001412.project_name: Port of Monrovia Dredging Project - Approach Roads

keywords.cdata: aircraft,asphalt,bauxite,berth,breakwaters,Bridge,buoys,buses,cargo,cargo traffic,carriers,cement,channels,cranes,crude oil,cy,Deadweight,Dredging,dry cargo,dwt,fork lift trucks,freight,freight costs,general cargo berths,grade,handling,highways,income,inspection,lighting,loading,loading equipment,manufacturing,mica,National Port Authority,navigational aids,oil refinery,ore,ore carriers,piers,pitch,Plaster,Port Development,port dues,port expansion,port facilities,port functions,Port Management,port users,public ports,railway lines,railways,rate of return,road traffic,roads,safety,sand,Scr,ship,ship waiting time,shipowners,shipping,shipping costs,ships,silt,stevedoring,storage charges,storage facilities,surfacing,tankers,temporary storage,timber,time in port,tonnage,Traffic,traffic lanes,transit,Transport,Transportation,trucks,tugs,UCC,vegetation,vehicles,vessels,Wharf

project_abstract.cdata: The project provides for dredging an area near the iron ore loading piers in the Port of Monrovia up to a depth of 45 feet to enable larger size ore carriers of up to about 90,000 DWT to enter the harbor, compared with a maximum of 45,000 DWT size the port can handle at present. It would also provide for two 1,250 horsepower tugs, a pilot launch, additional buoying and lighting for the channels, management assistance and engineering consultants' services. Feasibility studies for improving the road approaches to the port are included.
